text: Patients with NPDR @ PRP is not indicated for patients with mild or moderate NPDR.
Patients with cardiovascular dysfunction @ In cases of hypotension and impaired cardiac function, vasopressors and inotropic agents can be administered to maintain an appropriate blood pressure.
Patients with cirrhosis @ Oral BCAA granules are recommended for patients with hypoalbuminemia.
Patients with keloid @ Small scars with infectious foci are typically treated through surgical excision.
Patients with methylpropionic acidemia and pyruvic acidemia @ Total parenteral nutrition is the method of choice in infants with severe illness.
Patients with vascular gastrointestinal disease @ For severe bleeding not responding to endoscopic intervention, angiographic embolization or surgical treatment is warranted.
heart failure patients @ Nitrates are suitable for patients with acute heart failure who also have hypertension, myocardial ischemia due to coronary heart disease, or mitral regurgitation.
Patients with oral allergy syndrome @ For patients allergic to birch pollen and latex, avoiding causative food intake is the only the reliable treatment.

Patients with OSA @ For OSA patients with coexisting diabetes, commonly used antidiabetic medications are all suitable options, but efforts should be made to use medications that do not increase body weight whenever possible.
Patients with prostate cancer @ For low-risk prostate cancer, routine pelvic lymph node dissection is not recommended.

Children with bronchiolitis obliterans @ For patients with mild symptoms and a stable condition, direct inhalation of corticosteroids may be appropriate. For those with more severe symptoms or in the early stages of the disease, systemic administration of corticosteroids may be considered.

Patients with liver cancer @ For giant liver cancers, the anterior approach liver resection method with the last free ligament of the liver can be employed. In the case of multiple liver cancers, a combination of surgical resection and intraoperative ablation treatment can be considered.

Patients with NSCLC @ For patients with PD-L1 positivity (TPS ≥ 1%), monotherapy with lambrolizumab is feasible, and patients with high PD-L1 expression (TPS ≥ 50%) can also receive atezolizumab monotherapy.
Patients with HCV @ For patients with acute HCV, treatment with sofosbuvir/velpatasvir is recommended.
Patients with sclerosing cholangitis @ Colectomy is recommended in patients with high-grade colonic dysplasia or neoplasia.

Patients with airway inflammation @ For individuals with high mucus secretion, a combination of mucolytics, inhaled corticosteroids, antihistamines, and anticholinergic medications can be used for treatment.
Patients with PVT @ For patients with chronic PVT, anticoagulant therapy is recommended if there is a history of or current concurrent intestinal ischemia.

Patients with hallux valgus @ When the intermetatarsal angle (IMA) is less than 14° and the distal metatarsal articular angle (DMAA) is less than 10°, distal metatarsal osteotomy may be performed. If DMAA is between 10° and 15°, Chevron-Gerbert surgery is an option. When IMA is greater than 14°, procedures such as metatarsal neck (e.g., Scarf) or base osteotomy are necessary.

Patients with inflammatory bowel disease @ In patients where 5-ASA and corticosteroids failed, they recommended that treatment can be escalated with thiopurine, anti-TNF therapy, vedolizumab, or tofacitinib.
Patients with gastroesophageal reflux disease @ For patients with GERD with renal insufficiency, PPI can be used for treatment.

patients with hyponatremia @ In cases where the nervous system deteriorates and serum sodium concentration cannot be quickly measured, if conditions permit, intravenous injection of hypertonic saline should be considered to treat suspected hyponatremia.
Elderly patients with osteoporosis @ For elderly osteoporosis patients with low fracture risk or impaired kidney function, the option of using vitamin K2 to maintain bone health is available.
Patients with NSCLC @ For resectable stage III NSCLC, 2−3 cycles of preoperative neoadjuvant chemotherapy can be carried out with platinum-doublet.

Patients with alcoholic liver disease @ For alcohol abuse patients without intellectual disabilities, a single psychosocial intervention is effective, while for alcohol abuse patients who are also affected by intellectual disabilities, only a comprehensive combination of psychotherapy, cognitive behavioral therapy, motivational therapy, and comprehensive medical care is effective.

Patients with NSCLC @ Endoscopic interventional therapy may be considered for patients with central airway stenosis who refuse to be operated on. The technologies include thermal ablation (high frequency electrotome, radiofrequency ablation, APC, microwave, laser, etc.), photodynamic therapy, cryotherapy, airway stent etc.
Bacterial meningitis patients @ For children with communicating hydrocephalus, repeated lumbar puncture with cerebrospinal fluid drainage may be considered as a treatment option.
Patients with candidiasis @ Choose an echinocandin for moderately severe to severe illness and for patients with recent azole exposure.

Patient with gastric cancer @ If neoadjuvant chemotherapy is effective, the original treatment plan should be continued; if neoadjuvant chemotherapy is ineffective, the treatment plan should be changed, or targeted drugs such as apatinib should be added.

Patients with acute cholecystitis @ Gallbladder drainage may be an option in patients who failed conservative management after a variable time of 24 to 48 h and who present with strict contrain dications for surgery.

Patients with PVT @ For patients with reversible causes and no clear predisposition to thrombosis in acute PVT, it is recommended to provide at least 6 months of anticoagulant therapy. For patients with a predisposition to thrombosis in acute PVT, indefinite anticoagulant therapy is recommended.
Patients with sinusitis @ For acute bacterial sinusitis, administer an oral antimicrobial, amoxicillin, as a first-line agent.

Patients with acute calculus cholecystitis @ We suggest performing laparoscopic cholecyst-ectomy for ACC patients with A and B cirrhosis, patients with advanced age (including more than 80 years old) and patients who are pregnant.
Patients with PVT @ For patients with acute PVT, anticoagulant therapy is recommended if PVT has already involved the mesenteric veins.

Dysphagia patients @ In case of complete obstruction, emergency upper gastrointestinal endoscopy is necessary. If esophageal stricture, rings, or webs are identified, caution should be exercised when considering esophagoscopy dilation procedure.
Children with acute respiratory failure @ Newborns and children weighing <8kg can use nasal CPAP, and older children or children weighing >8kg can use BiPAP.

Patients with breast cancer @ For HER2-positive/HR-positive patients, if chemotherapy is not suitable or the disease progresses slowly, anti-HER2 therapy combined with endocrine drugs can be considered as first-line treatment options.

patients with CKD @ For overweight or obese patients with CKD stages 1-2 and diabetes, it is suggested that females reduce their calorie intake to 1,200-1,500 kcal/day, and males reduce their calorie intake to 1,500-1,800 kcal/day to achieve weight control goals.
Patients with sclerosing cholangitis @ Total proctocolectomy is recommended in the case of high grade dysplasia or adenocarcinoma or non-adenoma-like dysplastic lesions of any grade.
Patients with allergic rhinitis @ For cases with severe nasal blockade, concomitantly administer nasal topical vasoconstrictor to start treatment.

Patients with premature ventricular contractions @ For individuals without organic heart disease, relief of psychological stress is sufficient. Medication is only used for those who have recently experienced a heart attack or have arrhythmias caused by heart failure.

Patients with sclerosing cholangitis @ In compensated patients with high-risk varices, who have contraindications or intolerance to NSBBs, endoscopic band ligation is recommended to prevent ﬁrst variceal bleeding .

Patients with COVID-19 @ In cases of acute tracheobronchitis, individuals with severe dry cough may be appropriately treated with cough suppressants. For those with phlegm that is difficult to expectorate, the recommendation is to use expectorants or mucolytic agents. Routine use of antibiotics is not recommended, but for patients with yellow purulent sputum, antibiotic treatment is advised.
Patients with sclerosing cholangitis @ Patients with portal hypertension should be treated with non-selective beta blockers to prevent portal hypertension-related decompensation.
Patients with allergic reaction @ For the wheezing patient with anaphylaxis, minimize breath stacking and barotraumas by allowing adequate exhalation time.
Patients with metabolic alkalosis @ Patients with hypokalemia receive potassium supplementation, while those with hypochloremia receive physiological saline.
obese patients @ For overweight/obese children and adolescents, it is recommended to engage in at least 60 minutes of moderate to vigorous-intensity aerobic activity each day.
patients with CKD @ It is recommended that obese patients with CKD stage 1~2 diabetes reduce caloric intake to 1500 kcal/d.
obese patients @ For overweight/obese patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM), a treatment plan should be developed that includes dietary, physical activity, and behavioral interventions.
Patients with ureteral stones @ For pregnancy ureteral stones, ureteral catheter drainage or percutaneous nephrostomy drainage is used for treatment.

Elderly patients with osteoporosis @ In elderly osteoporosis patients experiencing severe pain or during the perioperative period of fractures, it is recommended to use calcitonin drugs, with a duration of use not exceeding 3 months.

Patients with acute heart failure @ For pregnant women or postpartum patients with extremely low ejection fraction in AHF, consideration may be given to anticoagulant therapy to prevent thromboembolism, and both low molecular weight heparin and warfarin are viable options.
Patients with hepatic pleural effusion @ For refractory hepatic hydrothorax patients who are not suitable for LT or TIPS, pleurodesis is recommended.

Patients with OSA @ For patients intolerant to continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP), APAP therapy is utilized. In cases where the treatment pressure exceeds 15 cmH2O with CPAP, bilevel positive airway pressure therapy is recommended.
Patients with deep vein thrombosis @ For patients in the chronic phase of deep venous thrombosis, intravenous active drugs are recommended.

Patients with vaginal laxity syndrome @ If a patient lacks columnar folds and does not have specific defects in a particular area, for those experiencing increased cervical mucus secretion, using CO2 laser to reduce some cervical glands may be considered.
Patients with breast cancer @ For HR-positive breast cancer patients with down-staging or breast-conserving needs, neoadjuvant chemotherapy should be recommended.
Patients with PSC @ For PSC patients with severe itching, medications such as cholestyramine, rifampicin, naltrexone, or ursodeoxycholic acid can be used for treatment.

Patients with primary biliary cholangitis @ For PBC patients without a history of kidney stones, 800-1,200 mg of calcium and 800-1,000 IU of vitamin D should be taken daily in the diet or supplements to prevent or treat osteoporosis.
Patients with NSCLC @ For patients with advanced age or low lung function, anatomical segmental or wedge resection plus systemic hilar or mediastinal lymph node dissection should be considered.

Patients with hyperglycemia @ It is recommended that women with tumors and diabetes should start taking a daily low dose of aspirin (100-150 mg) from weeks 12 to 16 of pregnancy to reduce the risk of preeclampsia.
Patients with gestational diabetes @ For diabetic pregnant women who refuse to take insulin, it is recommended to consider oral medications such as metformin or glyburide.

Patients with AI @ In cases where the patient lacks a willingness for surgery or adrenal vein sampling (AVS) determines bilateral secretion, treatment with a low dose of mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist (such as spironolactone) is recommended.

Patients with gastric venous bleeding @ In patients with mild gastroesophageal varices at risk of bleeding, the use of non-selective beta-blockers for treatment is recommended only when there is a significant risk of bleeding. Non-selective beta-blockers are not recommended when the risk of bleeding is modest.
Patients with primary aldosteronism @ In cases of unilateral Primary Aldosteronism, laparoscopic adrenalectomy is the treatment of choice.
Patients with acute cholecystitis @ Alternative treatment for patients with ACC who are not suitable for surgery: observation and techniques for gallbladder drainage.
Patients with gastroesophageal reflux disease @ We recommend considering magnetic sphincter augmentation (MSA) for treatment in patients with regurgitation who fail medical management.
heart failure patients @ Patients with acute heart failure accompanied by volume overload require a sodium intake of<2g/d.
Patients with knee osteoarthritis @ Patients who have a bleeding disorder, pacemaker, or could be pregnant may not be safe candidates for acupuncture.

Patients with pancreatic cancer @ For patients with life expectancy ≥3 months do not experience duodenal obstruction temporarily, prophylactic gastrojejunostomy could be performed if indicated clinically.

patients with lower esophageal ring @ For patients with a larger esophageal ring, instructing them to thoroughly chew food is the primary treatment approach. However, for a narrowed esophageal ring, endoscopic or bougie dilation may be necessary.
Patients with pancreatic cancer @ For resectable or borderline resectable patients, puncture biopsy is recommended for patients who cannot tolerate surgical resection for poor performance status.

Patients with WD @ Zinc supplements are suitable for pregnant patients and those intolerant to D-penicillamine. For children aged 5 to 15 and weighing less than 50 kg, the dose is 75 mg/day, administered orally in three divided doses. For children under 5 years, the dose is 50 mg/day, administered orally in two divided doses.
Patients with decompensated cirrhosis @ Therapeutic thoracentesis is indicated for patients experiencing respiratory distress.

Patients with HEV @ In cases where patients exhibit significant loss of appetite, frequent vomiting, and jaundice, besides rest and nutrition, intravenous administration of glucose solution, saline, and vitamin C can be considered.
Patients with allergic rhinitis @ For symptoms of sneezing and rhinorrhea type, start treatment by the combination of second-generation antihistamine and nasal topical steroids.
Patients with AI @ Patients with adrenal incidentalomas (AI) having a nodule diameter greater than 3 cm may be considered for surgical treatment.

Patients with colorectal cancer @ For patients with preoperative high nutritional risk or malnutrition, enteral nutrition (EN) is the preferred choice, and nutritional therapy should be provided for 10 to 14 days. If EN cannot meet the patient's energy requirements, preoperative PN therapy is recommended.
CBP and CP/CPPS patients @ If a patient is experiencing psychosocial symptoms, planned treatment strategies using stress management, including accounting for chronic pain cycles, may be considered.
Patients with GSDIa @ Liver transplantation may be considered for patients with severe metabolic failure.
Patients with hyperglycemia @ The preferred treatment approach for non-critically ill hospitalized patients with adequate nutritional intake is a premixed insulin regimen.

Patients with SAP @ Conservative treatment is advised when intra-abdominal pressure is sustained or repeatedly ≥12 mmHg. When intra-abdominal pressure exceeds 20 mmHg, and concomitant organ dysfunction is present, active non-operative interventions are recommended.

Patients with keloid @ For children aged 12 and below with keloids, it is advisable to avoid the use of anti-tumor chemotherapy drugs and radiation therapy. The primary treatment modalities for pediatric keloids should include silicone products, scar-reducing topical medications, and compression therapy.
Patients with hepatitis C @ Patients with a history of psychiatric illness should be given Direct-Acting Antivirals for HCV treatment without interferon.
Patients with allergic reaction @ For patients who develop bronchospasm, the sedative ketamine can be used after intubation.
Patients with keloid @ For patients with extremely large keloids, if there are significant underlying organ diseases and a high risk of anesthesia, a non-surgical treatment strategy is warranted.

Elderly patients with osteoporosis @ For elderly osteoporosis patients at high risk of vertebral or non-vertebral fractures with poor response, contraindications, or intolerance to bone resorption inhibitors, parathyroid hormone analogs may be considered. In the case of extremely high fracture risk in elderly individuals or severe osteoporosis, the use of parathyroid hormone analogs is recommended.
heart failure patients @ For patients with concurrent right ventricular failure, consideration should be given to a biventricular assist device.
Patients with herpetic Gingivostomatitis @ Immunocompetent patients with significant pain or refusal to drink can be administered oral acyclovir.
Patients with diarrhea @ For individuals with functional diarrhea or severe IBS symptoms, antidiarrheal medications may be administered to effectively alleviate diarrhea symptoms.

Patients with oral lichen planus @ For refractory or non-healing erosive lesions, topical corticosteroid local occlusive therapy can be considered, such as injection of triamcinolone acetonide (10-40mg once every 2-4 weeks) or dexamethasone injection (5mg once weekly).
Patients with peptic ulcer disease @ For patients with a history of ulcers, PPI treatment is recommended.
Patients with acute heart failure @ For patients with oliguria, combined with AKI and ineffective fluid resuscitation, renal replacement therapy may be considered.
Elderly patients with osteoporosis @ For patients who are intolerant or contraindicated to bisphosphonates, raloxifene can be used as an alternative treatment.
Patients with rheumatoid arthritis @ For patients with contraindications or early intolerance to methotrexate, leflunomide and sulfasalazine are good alternatives

Patients with sclerosing cholangitis @ In patients with sepsis and those who do not quickly respond to antibiotic treatment, the addition of antibiotic coverage against gram positive organisms, targeted against Enterococci, such as glyco peptide antibiotics (e.g. vancomycin) or oxazolide antibiotics (e.g. linezolid) may be an option.
Patients with DILI @ Liver transplantation can be an effective treatment when internal therapy is not sufficiently effective, or the patient develops decompensated cirrhosis or acute liver failure.

Patients with acute heart failure @ For patients with cardiogenic shock, early initiation of mechanical circulatory support is recommended, along with emergency cesarean section to terminate the pregnancy.
Patients with alcohol withdrawal syndrome  @ Inject glucose intravenously when hypoglycemia occurs, and short-acting sedatives should be used to control symptoms in severe patients.

Patients with COVID-19 @ For ordinary patients without fever, without headache, and without muscle pain, routine use of antibiotics, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, and the isolated use of central cough suppressants are not recommended. It is recommended to use combination formulations containing first-generation antihistamines, decongestants, and cough suppressants. In cases of severe cough, central or peripheral cough suppressants may be used if necessary.
Patients with methylpropionic acidemia and pyruvic acidemia @ Extracorporeal detoxification is commonly used in severely decompensated patients.
